summary: Reporter asks why SkiaSharp NuGet doesn't auto-include Linux NativeAssets — this is by-design because Linux has no TFM and requires manual package selection between NativeAssets.Linux (fontconfig) and NoDependencies variants

stepsToReproduce: Have a transitive dependency that pulls in an older SkiaSharp.NativeAssets.Linux (e.g. 2.88.7)
Run on Linux in GitHub Actions CI
Observe version mismatch: native library 88.1 vs expected [119.0, 120.0)
reproEvidence.environmentDetails: Linux runner in GitHub Actions CI, SkiaSharp 3.119.0 (reported), transitive NativeAssets.Linux 2.88.7

versionAnalysis.relevanceReason: Linux NativeAssets are still not auto-included in SkiaSharp 3.x — this is by design and documented. The reporter's confusion about why Linux is excluded persists across versions.

analysis.summary: Reporter believes it's a bug that SkiaSharp.csproj doesn't include a ProjectReference to NativeAssets.Linux, but this is intentional. Unlike Android, iOS, macOS, and Windows, Linux has no platform-specific TFM (there is no 'net8.0-linux'). Additionally, Linux requires users to choose between two mutually exclusive variants: NativeAssets.Linux (with fontconfig) and NativeAssets.Linux.NoDependencies (no external deps). The version mismatch error occurs because a transitive dependency pulls in an old NativeAssets.Linux version, and no explicit PackageReference pins it to the correct version.
analysis.rationale: Classified as question (not bug) because the behavior is by design and documented in documentation/packages.md. The SkiaSharp.csproj correctly omits Linux because (1) there's no -linux TFM to condition on, (2) Linux has two incompatible native variants requiring user selection, and (3) auto-including would force unnecessary binary downloads. The reporter's proposed fix (adding a ProjectReference with Condition="$(TargetFramework.Contains('-linux'))") wouldn't work because .NET doesn't have a -linux TFM. The actual fix is adding an explicit PackageReference to the correct NativeAssets.Linux variant in the application project. Area is libSkiaSharp.native because this is about native asset packaging and deployment.

keySignals.text: SkiaSharp.NativeAssets.Linux v2.88.7 is being included as a transient package rather than v3.119.0
keySignals.interpretation: A transitive dependency (likely another library) is pulling in an old NativeAssets.Linux version. Without an explicit PackageReference at the app level, NuGet resolves to the transitive version.

keySignals.text: SkiaSharp references every other platform's native assets. So why does it not reference Linux?
keySignals.interpretation: Valid observation, but the answer is: no -linux TFM exists, and Linux has two variants requiring user choice. macOS and Win32 are included for non-platform TFMs via !$(TargetFramework.Contains('-')).

keySignals.text: Linux having multiple distros, C libraries etc. and needing a mechanism with NuGet to support the different configurations
keySignals.interpretation: Community member correctly explains the design rationale — Linux's variant matrix (glibc vs musl, fontconfig vs no-deps) prevents automatic inclusion.
Proposed fix won't work — .NET has no -linux TFM. The condition would never match.

codeInvestigation.finding: NativeAssets ProjectReferences exist for Android (-android), iOS (-ios), MacCatalyst (-maccatalyst), macOS (-macos or non-platform), Tizen (-tizen), tvOS (-tvos), Win32 (-windows or non-platform). Linux is intentionally absent — no -linux TFM exists in .NET.

Documentation explicitly states NativeAssets.Linux, NativeAssets.Linux.NoDependencies, NativeAssets.WebAssembly, and NativeAssets.NanoServer must be added manually. This is documented behavior, not a bug.

AllTargetFrameworks = BasicTargetFrameworks + PlatformTargetFrameworks. PlatformTargetFrameworks includes ios, maccatalyst, android, tizen, tvos, macos, windows — but NOT linux. .NET SDK does not define a linux platform TFM.

Uses BasicTargetFrameworks (not AllTargetFrameworks), targets netstandard2.0/2.1/net462/net8.0. Ships runtimes for linux-x64, linux-x86, linux-arm64, linux-arm, linux-riscv64, linux-loongarch64, plus musl variants. Requires fontconfig.
Same architecture matrix as NativeAssets.Linux but from linuxnodeps/alpinenodeps build output. No fontconfig dependency. Two competing packages for the same RIDs — user must choose one.

workarounds: Add an explicit PackageReference to SkiaSharp.NativeAssets.Linux (or NoDependencies) matching your SkiaSharp version in the application project
If a transitive dependency pulls in an old version, the explicit PackageReference at the app level will override it via NuGet's nearest-wins resolution
nextQuestions: Which transitive dependency is pulling in SkiaSharp.NativeAssets.Linux 2.88.7? A binlog would confirm.
Is the reporter using NativeAssets.Linux or NativeAssets.Linux.NoDependencies? The choice affects fontconfig requirements.

resolution.hypothesis: A transitive NuGet dependency brings in an old NativeAssets.Linux version. The fix is adding an explicit PackageReference to the matching version in the application project. Linux not being auto-included is by design.

proposals.title: Add explicit NativeAssets.Linux PackageReference
proposals.description: Add a direct PackageReference to SkiaSharp.NativeAssets.Linux (or NoDependencies) at the same version as SkiaSharp in the application project. This overrides the transitive old version via NuGet's nearest-wins resolution.

proposals.title: Use NoDependencies variant for CI/containers
proposals.description: If running in GitHub Actions or containers without fontconfig, use NativeAssets.Linux.NoDependencies instead. This has zero third-party dependencies.

proposals.title: Identify the transitive dependency source
proposals.description: Run 'dotnet build --binary-logger' and inspect the binlog with MSBuild Structured Log Viewer to find which package transitively references the old NativeAssets.Linux 2.88.7. Then either update that package or pin the version.

resolution.recommendedReason: Simplest fix — one line in the csproj. Directly resolves the version mismatch by overriding the transitive dependency.

actionability.reason: By-design behavior documented in packages.md. The workaround (explicit PackageReference) is well-established and resolves the issue. Multiple community members in #3117 confirmed this approach works.

Explain by-design behavior and provide workaround
actions.comment:
Thanks for raising this — it's a common source of confusion.

Linux NativeAssets are intentionally not auto-included by the SkiaSharp package. Unlike iOS, Android, macOS, and Windows, .NET doesn't have a `-linux` TFM, so there's no condition to match on. Additionally, Linux has two mutually exclusive variants — `NativeAssets.Linux` (requires fontconfig for system font enumeration) and `NativeAssets.Linux.NoDependencies` (zero external dependencies, for containers) — so the user needs to choose which one fits their deployment.

The version mismatch you're seeing (native 88.1 vs expected 119.0) is because a transitive dependency is pulling in an old `NativeAssets.Linux`. Here's the fix — add an explicit reference in your **application** project:

```xml
<PackageReference Include="SkiaSharp.NativeAssets.Linux" Version="3.119.0" />
```

Or if you're in a minimal container / CI without fontconfig:

```xml
<PackageReference Include="SkiaSharp.NativeAssets.Linux.NoDependencies" Version="3.119.0" />
```

This overrides the transitive version via NuGet's nearest-wins resolution. To identify which package is pulling in the old version, you can run `dotnet build --binary-logger` and inspect the binlog.

This is documented in the [NuGet packages documentation](https://github.com/mono/SkiaSharp/blob/main/documentation/packages.md#auto-included-nativeassets) under "Must be added manually."
